stories.text:
Something I hope to try out soon but would be very happy if anyone beats me to it / can point me to something like this that already exists.

Basic Idea ----------

A browser extension that hides comments on YouTube, Reddit, Twitter and Instagram.

Toggle needs to be convenient so users can 'reveal' comments on demand.

An implementation for apps would be great but guessing it can't be done.

There is an extension that hides YouTube comments but it's not easily toggled and is just limited to YouTube. https://chrome.google.com/webstore/detail/hide-youtube-comments/kehdmnjmaakacofbgmjgjapbbibhafoh?hl=en

Rationale is to help with mindfulness, explained more in Background.

Broader Idea -------------

Extension tracking user navigation through sites (keeping all data local) that can identify 'autopilot patterns' and lets them configure indicators to gently let them know.

Could also provide digests / live metrics with an estimate on time spent in autopilot.

It's really important things are presented in a super non-judgemental way and are easily toggled; it shouldn't be like the anti-distraction apps that can feel imposing rather than supporting.

Background ----------

I noticed that over lockdown I would spend a lot of time browsing YouTube on autopilot so, as an experiment, I started using an extension that hides comments.

This set-up gave me an instant "you're on autopilot" signal because most of the times I switch off, I will scroll down to the comments at some point.

I spend way less time on YouTube now but I feel like I'm getting so much more out of it.

I'm more open to watching videos that I wouldn't normally choose to; one's outside of my normal interests and ones that I know I won't like.

When watching these I can see how my ego 'fires' with themes of "I don't like this person" or "this is really shallow", and how that often triggers autopilot.

When I can catch it at the moment, which happens more and more often, I can turn my attention to what I do like about what I'm seeing or what things I can empathize with.

It's made my world a bit bigger and has been a nice way of adding a bit more mindfulness to my day.

Of course I know other people's responses will likely be very different, interested to know how it affects different people on different sites.
